Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2013 07:56PM LittleFlower wrote: oh Cathy, I feel your pain. I thought I was doing well until I had the worst anxiety panic attack the day before starting chemo. It took me a year to try the anxiety meds, and almost two to take an antidepressant. In retrospect, had I started the meds in the beginning of treatment I may have tolerated it better. I was SO depressed, I couldn't leave the house. I didn't realize how bad it was until I took the help and realized how much better I felt. I never wanted to be on meds, but this was just too much for me to handle on my own. Good luck with your treatments my dear. It does get better, it does get easier, but you don't have to be a martyr. Take every bit of help that's offered, and then ask for more if you need it! Hugs, little flower
Posts.Title: Meltdown today cathy1955 pipers_dream

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 08:23PM LittleFlower wrote: Deb, The ativan helped me through chemo, and helped me sleep during treatment.  The one thing i'll say is that i was taking a .25mg and it worked ok for a little while, then i felt like i needed .5mg and then i felt like i needed it more often (rather than just every once and a while)  My onc switched me to klonopin - written for upto 2 pills (.50mg) a day.  I take 0.25mg everyday and that works great.  The reason i bring this up is that the klonopin is longer lasting, i found the ativan was wearing off after 6-8 hours and the klonopin lasts about 12 hours so i don't have the anxiety starting at night like i did with ativan. I also take an SSRI and with both these i can be functional- which i wasn't able to be for a long time after my diagnosis.  I used to hesitate to accept help, now i'll take whatever makes this life a little more bearable! good for you for taking the first step to feeling better. LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2011 07:35PM LittleFlower wrote: rabbit, I just read your first post.  I remember the night after my first infusion, just a few hours later, i felt like a MAC truck had run me over.  It was terrible!  The first infusion for me was tough, the next several were different - not as bad I guess.  I always had a little nausea, never vomit though.  I don't think your response to the first one is any indication of how the rest will go.  For some reason they were all a little different for me.  I'm glad to hear you're feeling better now, hope the rest of your treatment is smooth. hugs, LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2009 05:07AM LittleFlower wrote: Thanks for all the replies... seems like most are getting atleast some bloodwork.  I do go to my PCP for that once a year, wonder if that's just not enough.  I guess it's obvious that i'm not comfortable with my onc.  In fact, a few months back, i felt a swollen lymph node on my neck.. of course i called and went in 2 days later.. when i spoke to the nurse on the phone, she said stop in and get your blood drawn before you come up to see us.  So i did.  I checked in at the front desk and the girl asked "get your blood drawn?"  yup.  Saw onc, she felt it, said she has a node 'just like it' that sometimes swells up and that this wasn't cancer.  (well that's reassuring i thought, did you have stage 3 cancer too? hmm) well, before she left the room i asked "how was all my blood work?"  She said... "you had blood work???  I'll check it and call you if there is anything wrong with it"  I asked "what should i do about this lymph node?" she said, we'll monitor it at your next visit (2.5 mos away) , so i touched it to get a feel for how big it was, and she said "don't touch it!"   So how reassuring is all that?  FYI the node went down,  remembered having a bug bite near it the week before on a hike so that reassured me... however at my next onc visit it was NEVER mentioned... they don't even review your record apparently before you're seen. i'm really not trying to make this a complaining session about my onc.  i think i know deep down inside that i would love to see someone else who at least could act like they care.  This thread i suppose was to realize that my intuition is right and that most people do feel comfortable with their docs.  Thanks again, LittleFLower
Posts.Title: What tests are done at your follow up visits?? LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2008 09:32PM LittleFlower wrote: Jen I am sooo sorry for this terribe news you've received.  I haven't read the other posts but trust they are very helpful as they usually are.  I just wanted to jump in and say there are many women who live with Stage 4 cancer for years, i know chemo sounds scary, but it is doable.  you should seriously consider it, and talk with you doc to ease your fears.  you should post on the board for meta. and recurrence and hear others who are doing chemo - if it's an option for you you may get more time than you're thinking.  i can only imagine the deep shock you're feeling right now- don't give up on yourself so quickly. (((((((HUGS))))))))))))) Little Flower

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 06:18PM LittleFlower wrote: hi tomato, sorry you're going through the roughest time right now- diagnosis.  i was diagnosed in june of 06 and with all the reading i'd done i thought my prognosis was terrible too being er neg and her2+ but my oncologist reassured me that her 2 treatments are so promising, she made me feel much better about it.  there are specific targeted treatments for her2 positive cancers.  don't worry about what the books say about prognosis. you are an individual person....you're not a statistic.  concentrate on having the surgery. it's the most important part, then worry about the rest.  it's too much to take in at once i know..........you'll be ok sweetie.  just know you're not alone.  there is also a her2 positive group on this website.  good luck sweetie with your surgery, come back and chat anytime LIttleFlower

Posts.Title: Oh Nooooooo JoyRebecca Dorathy

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 11:22AM - edited Aug 19, 2009 11:24AM by LittleFlower tovashmom, good question.  What is the next step for you?  Personally, i think whatever the pathology report states (in terms of size, receptor status, grade etc) you should see a medical oncologist for some opinion of treatment.  It may be you don't need further treatment, or maybe something more could help fight a recurrence?  I don't know what a 'little cancer' means, but i would definitely get an opinion on further treatment or it's necessity for that matter. I speak from personal experience with a family member.  Before i was diagnosed with breast cancer my mil had a lumpectomy, she was being followed by her breast surgeon, never saw a med. oncologist, and i think that her life may have been different had she seeked a second opinion.  It's easy to say, oh just a little cancer, go into a safe place and move on with life, but cancer is vicious so make sure you know what you  need to do to make sure you remain cancer free.  Really not trying to be  a downer here, just that your post struck a cord with me since a family member has been down a similar path.......Hope your healing goes quickly following your recent lumpectomy. HUGS, LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 04:50PM LittleFlower wrote: Hi LC, wanted to send you a Gentle hug ((((HUGS)))))) You are loved my dear, i pray that you have comfort and peace today.  I love the funny stories shared above, wish i wasn't so darn serious so I could think of one too for you!  Silliest thing that happened so far today:  I took my DS for a walk (he's nine months old)  trying to get him to take his morning nap.  The weather is certainly miserable in NY today.  So i'm walking him and one of our dear little cats (who is actually an enormous black loving cat) is following us.  We get to a certain point and cat refuses to go any further.  So what a silly sight it was, carrying a big back cat in one arm, pushing the stroller with the other, and needless to say, baby watching cat whole time therefore not sleeping.. yeah got a few looks from the neighbors, but they must know i'm strange by now......the bald one, who now has a baby, and two crazy cats.......hahaha. Hope you can find a smile my friend, LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 05:34AM LittleFlower wrote: Thanks ladies for your encouraging words.  I remember a member posting a few months back (can't remember who!) that she had been reassured she had arthritis, and later was really diagnosed with bone mets.  I don't have to explain it to you guys, this is just scary stuff.  I'll take the good news!  Actually, i was really worried that they'd find other mets, numerous, that weren't affecting me at all.. so i was pretty happy to learn that 3 years post dx, and 2 years post tx, my bones are ok. (how surreal, as i type those years in I realize it hasn't been that long.. but it truly feels like an eternity.  I am SO READY to leave this all behind me!) Prayers for everyone on these boards that good news will follow you all as well! LittleFlower
Posts.Title: arthritis on recent bone scan... really? LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 06:19PM LittleFlower wrote: Wow, how refreshing to find this thread.  At my last 3 month follow up, Fatigue was my biggest complaint.  I finished treatment at the end of 2007.  i'm thinking i should be feeling better by now!  So when i told my onc's nurse practitioner that this was my biggest problem, she asked me  " are you sleeping in the night?"  ummm my answer was... "yes... and then some"  then she proceeded to tell me that i should exercise more, because she feels tired when she doesn't exercise... yeah that's right, the situations are totally comparable.  This 20 something year old girl is going to compare my fatigue to hers after my body has been through a war! Just venting... feels good to let it out.  Seems like no one has an answer as to why we feel so tired! LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2009 08:17PM LittleFlower wrote: Hi Beth, I had a bilateral in 2006.  I wore foam filled forms for about a year... maybe longer.  My silicone forms are ameona brand and i love them.  they are very comfortable and natural looking.  In retrospect i wish i had started wearing them sooner ( like you're doing) because i think they just look SOO much better, but thinking back, i was in chemo, and radiation and the last thing i cared about was how i looked.  I suppose the point is this is going to be a yearly thing.  The first fitting is a little scary, cause it's something new.  My only advice is don't be shy to tell the fitter if you don't like something.  My first pair was very round (versus teardrop shaped) and i didn't like those as much, but felt like i had to take them. good luck, maybe you could take someone you trust to ease the anxiety. LittleFlower
Posts.Title: Nervouse about getting prosthesis for the first time BethHG nagem

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 09:46PM - edited Jul 26, 2012 09:47PM by LittleFlower Need, It's funny.  During treatment you're very active, always doing something... like one appointment or another.  At the same time, it's like the world has stopped.  All you're focused on is cancer and chemo and surgery.. blah blah blah.  Once you make that first move to get back into the 'real world', there will be some powerful momentum, and one good thing will lead to another... it might be a really good part of your treatment emotionally, to remember what it's like to be in control of a situation!  Basically, if you don't do it, you'll never know what could of been.  GO FOR IT GIRL!!

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2008 12:50PM LittleFlower wrote: Jenny, i just wanted to tell you that i also had bilateral breast cancer.  While It is not common, it was comforting to know that our prognosis is not any worse because of the bilateral thing.  it is based on the bigger tumor, the more involved side. There are so many unanswered questions with this whole breast cancer journey.. i was diagnosed in 06.  while in the hospital recovering from a bilat. mastectomy, i met another young woman who had just had the same diagnosis as us.  To date, we are the only three i have heard of that have had the bilateral breast cancer (both breasts involved simultaneously).  I know that she had tested positive for the brca gene and that i didn't.  Did you?  i don't know if genetics plays a role in it or not.  Anyways, though it's rare, i don't think it makes us too different in the grand scheme of things.......... take care.. big hugs LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 01:07PM LittleFlower wrote: Hi Zarowny, I haven't read the other responses because i just wanted to jump in with my two cents.  Of course, as we know, there is no easy answer. Here's what i think... Maybe you  could try the chemo first being closely monitored because this way you get the comfort of systemic treatment.  Then if there is response it will be seen in your nodes....then maybe the next step could be to do radiation if there is not complete resolution in the nodes.  The chemo can shrink the nodes then finish them off with rads, or it could just Kill the damn cancer all together!  It's such a tough decision...........i am so sorry you find yourself trying to make this decision.  The good thing about rads is that if you debulk and kill off all that cancer then there is a reduced chance of it spreading.  I guess what i would weigh the side effects of the chemo into the equation too.  Gee i see your dilema, can you do both??  kind of like if you have a primary bc then do the chemo and the rads?  so sorry hon, please let us know how it goes..... Little Flower

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 06:39PM LittleFlower wrote: update on Tabby..Prayers are heard! blood work this am showed that her kidney enzymes were down pancreatic up, ultrasound helped to dx pancreatitis.   She seems comfortable but still vomitting and not eating.  treatment is iv fluids, so there she stays for a few more days on liquids and electrolytes. then hopefully hometime!  The vet today seemed pretty optimistic and Tabby seemed pretty angry with me that she was still there LOL. She is ususally so mild but today the techs called her sassy!  I think it's a good sign.  The ER vet yesterday was pretty sure kidney dz with 50/50 chance of making it.  I will only be truly happy when she's with me again, at home, purring next to me.  I told her there would be lots of prayers for her!  THANKS SISTERS for being there, as you always are! Love, LittleFlower.... PS i'll let you know when the really good news comes and she gets discharged from the hospital!
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2009 08:26PM - edited Aug 13, 2009 08:27PM by LittleFlower How kind of you all to inquire Tabby is quite the survivor.  She's hasn't vomited in 3 days!  That's really good.  She'll eat but very little.  i have to hand feed her the hard little bits of food.  she will not eat her canned food, but will surprise me sometime with a few bits of deli turkey.  she is drinking her water when coaxed.  All in all i'd say she's stable. The drastic weight loss has left her frail, but hopefully with time she'll pick up a few ounces.  She, like most cats, likes to do things in her own time! LOL.  I read her these messages when i sign on.. and i truly believe that prayer pulled her through this awful episode.  I didn't think i'd have her long after she was admitted in the hospital.  one of the er vets had me online choosing a little casket for her ( the way he doom and gloomed the situation) Anyways!  Thanks again for checking... i'll let you all know if there is any change in status! LittleFlower
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 12:12PM LittleFlower wrote: Update on Tabby:  We're getting better at the force feeding- i think she's finds Gerbers Ham 'acceptable'.   She actually nibbled some food on her own last night ( i heard her in the middle of the night- since she sleeps by my side, i have a little bowl of food on the floor right there)  When she's in the right mood she might eat a treat (tender chicken treats).  I spoke to a vet tech the other night from the hospital.  She said cats can be THAT fussy.  She will not eat anything  and we've tried alot of different brands, both hard and soft, grilled, chunky, gravy, solid, minced... baby food, cat milk.........the list goes on and on.  She's so fussy she's willing to starve to death?  i don't get it.  Anyhow, the plan is if she doesn't start eating on her own, an appetite stimulant will be rx'd for her.  The thought of her going back to the hospital makes me ill, even if it's just for follow up.  She seems comfortable... she's got some spunk back.  It's kind of funny.  If anyone out there has force fed cats before, you know it can be messy!  So my hubby holds her wrapped in a towel, and i happily speak to her and put this syringe into the side of her mouth, and she kinda licks it up.. well today when we put her down on the bed when we were done, she walked away grumbling something LOL  If she wasn't such a lady i would think she was swearing at us, too funny. Hoping this is just a slow road to recovery, and not a slow process in the other direction.  It's hard to tell sometimes   But it is very comforting to know you all care and ask about her.  I really tell her every single time... to give her some strength to fight through this tough time.  THANKS.... from Tabitha and myself!
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 10:56PM LittleFlower wrote: Reading all your stories just makes me smile.  I love it!  My cats are my children too.  Anne: I'm so HAPPY Miso is eating!  Little devil, worrying you so!  She's probably threatening you so you never leave her again lol Tabitha is doing better.  She's really herself but just weaker.  We've stopped force feeding her, she seems to be eating (though very little) on her own.  She just seems to have aged all of a sudden, but this could be the dramatic weight loss she's had. Currently, as I type, my other baby, Austin (our black halloween cat) is chasing mosquitoes through the house... don't know how they got it, but they're keeping him entertained.  Good thing,cause when Austin's bored, Tabitha gets picked on!  He's just a chubby little one year old who truly believes the world revolves around him! We must have spoiled him.... it's so hard not to. I'm really glad Tabs is better, and all the posts asking about her helped.  I read them all to her! Thanks all, and keep the thread alive... meomommies unite! (CMHARRIS .. your posts make me laugh... your choice words are so creative LIttleFlower
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2009 08:48PM LittleFlower wrote: Anne, i know what you mean about the shaved paws.. they also shaved Tabby's and her belly for ultrasound too.  She was so conscious about her legs shaved, she sat in such a way as they were never curled or touching anything when she got home. I'm such a lunatic when she's in the hospital.  She had a tooth extraction about 3 years ago.  She was to stay at the vets all day, come home at 5 pm.  After her procedure, i went in and sat with her for like 2 hours.  The vet finally said, "i think she'll be ok if you take her"  .. i think i was in the way.. oops! Coonie, are your dachshounds long or short hair? Those little doggies just have the cutest little mugs.  ((((Kathleen)))) and ((((Oliver)))) big hugs your way.  Poor little Oli.. i hate when they have to stay overnight.  Surely, he'll realize it's for his own good when he starts feeling alot better!  You're just being a great mom right now just to remind you. C: isn't it funny how they feel so safe with you.. really makes you feel the love.  I've always believed that animals are a great judge of character!  Goodnight to all the meowmy's and EXTRA SPECIAL THOUGHTS AND PRAYERS FOR OLIVER AND HIS MOM! LittleFLower

Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2009 09:02AM LittleFlower wrote: Quick Tabby udate.. She took a long walk around the perimeter of the house yesterday!  The weather was so perfect, she wanted to sit on the porch in a stream of sun, then the little lady slowly started wandering through the landscaping LOL she took her time and was out there almost an hour.  Since she's only allowed out supervised, and i was looking quite crazy out there in my pink pj's at 10 am i encouraged her to come in.  She went out later after dinner again!  She must be feeling better .... she hasn't acted this way in over a year!  Though she's not a Gerber baby anymore her appetite is still minimal.  Hopefully we'll get there.  Amazing, one month ago today she was in the hospital and i didn't think she'd make it ... i told her yesterday she's a true survivor! LittleFlower
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 07:06PM LittleFlower wrote: Oh Coonie, He is so teeny!  What a cute baby!  How much does Opie weigh?  how old is he? Hehehe what a cutie! BTW:  Tabitha is eating some canned food, couple bites in the AM..Thank God! LittleFlower
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2009 05:42PM LittleFlower wrote: you wouldn't believe how cold it has gotten in the north east.. boy feels like we missed fall all together and jumped into winter.  We've had alot of rain too.  Anyhow, the point of my post... i bought Tabby a little heating pad for cats... it's cute.  It has a little bean bag insert thingy that you microwave for a few seconds, put it back in the furry soft covering that is shaped like a small blanket and voila.  So today, she acutally accepted it!  Poor thing, with all the weight she lost i swear she's just frozen like a little popsicle all day.  We DO have the heat on, but she's just so little.. anyhow, got the heating pad thing at petsmart and i think it's great for older pets who need a little extra something. head bumps to the babies! LittleFLower
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 09:03PM LittleFlower wrote: ((((CM)))))))))) So Sorry to hear about Boo.  Sounds like you were a great mom to her for almost 12 years, born right into your arms.. so sweet.  Just a beautiful cat in those photos.....i feel so sad for you right now.  I hope her siblings are doing well.  I've been thinking of the furmommies lately.  You were all so great during Tabby's bout with pancreatitis.  Though she hasn't gained back much of the weight she had lost, she's sleeping on my lap right now.  Little munchkin has aged so much since she's been sick, but i'll take everyday i can with her.  Sometimes i get so paranoid that cancer might take me before my little old lady... back to the "I HATE CANCER" mode for the last little while.  These furry babies make everyday better.  God Bless them all, and their moms too! LittleFlower
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 01:15PM LittleFlower wrote: Zar, i just had to chime in again. I had met a girl when i was diagnosed who had an intermammary node.  She started with her chemo, and shortly before she was done with her treatment (ER-/HER2+) she was diagnosed with mets.  She had responded to chemo because her intermammary node had shrunk but did not resolve completely.  This node was there for about 8 months before her mets were found.  I remember thinking to myself, i wish they had Radiated that damn node right up front because i saw it as a possible cause for systemic spread.  I want to say that GETTING RID OF THE CANCER the quickest way might be the way to go....if that's rads..then it's rads.  That chemo you mentioned will always be in your arsenal if you ever need it (God willing you never will)  Sorry for being so much on the fench but after typing my last post, i thought of my good friend who had a 'similar' situation in that she had one node that just wasn't responding to chemo.  find out if there are any ways to minimize side effects... any options with doses?  Good luck, wishing you some peace of mind. LittleFlower
Posts.Title: Ladies Please Help Me,I feel Like it's crunch time.. zarowny9 Trevorrolph

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2010 09:30PM LittleFlower wrote: Hi RealtorJackie (((HUGS))) Sorry about your recent diagnosis.  I remember waiting for chemo to start... you'll be surprised as the days go by how quickly you will bounce back.... just be kind to yourself, before you know it this will all be a distant memory (or nightmare ) take care, post often LittleFlower
Posts.Title: I'm In the Club RealtorJackie Maureen813

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 09:47AM LittleFlower wrote: Stephanie, I can relate, like so many other women on these boards!  I've had this pain in my left hip for well over a year.  I reluctantly had a bone scan about 1 year ago, after dealing with the on and off pain for about 6 months or so.  Scan showed arthritis, no mets. Of course I was ecstatic, you feel like you got a new lease on life again... but here I am one year later, pain in my left hip, on and off... can't help but think is it really arthritis or should i have another scan to verify no mets, were they too small last time?  will they find something somewhere else... What the heck!  I feel your angst.  Sometimes I'm not sure how to present things to my onc either and with an appt coming up in the next week or so I start to feel the worry too.  Sorry for rambling.. I guess if you really want to know, get it checked.  Sooner is better i'd guess, but really it's a tough world we live in isn't it?  Gentle Hugs my dear, LittleFLower

((MUMAYAN))) really sorry to hear what you had to go through with your kitty.  They're so special, and when they're sick we're so helpless....Big hugs to you LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 09:11PM LittleFlower wrote: Well, Tabby came home Wednesday night.  All good that night... she was SO happy.  That night was great, i love having her sleep with me at night.  Yesterday was rough, she's been vomitting... we've been giving her anti nausea injections.. today she ate a little and so far no vomit!  Taking it one hour at a time, she's looking really frail.  I wish it was more cut and dry, like sick then better!  So please continue praying she's on her road to recovery!  Called the vet today and left a message, didn't even get a call back!  Man, i'm so tired of dealing with unknowns! So good news is She's home! bad news is she's not quite herself yet :( Thanks again for thinking of us, makes us feel better (i'll pass on your good wishes) LittleFLower

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 10:16PM LittleFlower wrote: Hey Jenny, I was also the first in my family to have breast cancer.  My treatment was 4 AC, 12 taxol with herceptin, then herceptin x1 year, followed by 6 weeks of rads (35 i think, funny that i can't remember, thought i'd never forget any of the details!) I have not had reconstruction.  The thought of any more surgeries was overwhelming at first, and at this point in my life, i just finished treatment less than a year ago, and am just getting comfortable with myself.. not ready for big changes again.   Where do you live?  sounds like maybe you in Canada just judging by rads #, but just a wild guess.  I'm in NY. take care.LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2008 06:29PM LittleFlower wrote: wow, i felt like i had a dirty little secret with my UGLY toenails!  It all started with a little athlete's foot before chemo, to full blown ugly nail fungus during chemo.  it is so hard to get rid of!  i am just about to start a topical treatment, but like others have eluded to, it is expensive stuff. i hope it works!  My hubby has a fingernail that is slighly fungusized and i had read that soaking in vinegar and water is helpful, so he's been doing that for a couple weeks (he's better at sticking to a regimen :0) and feels like it is starting to work! if nothing else, thank goodness for nail polish! LittleFlower

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 04:05PM LittleFlower wrote: so i had my appt, my hip pain has gradually subsided ( after about 6 weeks of on again off again) and i decided.. NO SCAN.  I can't take it.  My onc probably would have ok'd it, had i really wanted one, but i just want to live in denial i guess.  Tough choices we're faced with aren't they?  At the beginning of this journey i would have accepted monthly scans!  now that i'm farther out from treatment, i don't want to go back to that place in my life... i want it to stay in the past!  Only The Lord knows what the future holds, so for now it's back to one day at a time, until my next follow up.  Thanks for all the support, each passing day is a struggle to deal with this disease and all the emotional baggage it brings with it. Hugs to all, LittleFlower
Posts.Title: hip pain LittleFlower NancyD

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 09:35AM LittleFlower wrote: Maybe you could call the American Cancer Society to get a list of places close to you.. or maybe their website.  I can't believe your surgeon said that! My surgeon encouraged me to get a second opinion, but i didn't.  The point is, it's not outrageous to ask for a second opinion, maybe to ACS could recommend that as well.  In my case, i just wanted to get my surgery over with, i didn't have options, it was pretty much a bilateral mastectomy, so i suppose i didn't really want a second opinion for that reason.  Deciding on types of surgery can be difficult though.  Good Luck. ((HUGS)) LIttleFlower

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 08:14AM LittleFlower wrote: It seems like you all have TM tests, i have never had one.  My follow up visits are very uneventful, meaning not much is done, other that a feel here and there.  I HATE FOLLOW UPS.  I don't get ANY blood work.  Should I? Posts.Title: TM Test - not run everyminute apple

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2013 08:53PM LittleFlower wrote: Though I can't answer your question about this particular doctor, I was In a similar situation. The cancer hospital I was at had this one surgeon that everybody talked about. He was THE best. I didn't see him but saw the newer surgeon, and you know what, she is an angel. I couldn't have asked for a better experience with respect to the surgery. I also had a double mastectomy. You should still do your research on this doctor, but also meet her and see what impression you get. Glad to hear that you're responding well to treatment. Best wishes for continued speedy recovery, (hugs).
Posts.Title: Sunnybrook Toronto, surgeon Dr. Look Hong. Opinions? Tafard Bozenag

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 09:37AM LittleFlower wrote: MLM i just wanted to welcome you.  You've taken a good step by joining the boards, because i found alot of support just reading about others' experiences, it made me feel less alone in the whole thing.  Having said that, reading your post reminds me alot of how i felt in june of 06 when i was diagnosed- it really makes my heart ache for you.  all i can tell you is what i've learned, and that is, you're part of a special community of women now, and that you may feel terrified, alone and ready to go along with God's plan,but the truth is, it's ok to be scared, you're not alone, and God answers prayers!  So keep posting, take it one day at a time.  eventually you will give yourself the permission you need to take it easy.  You'll see, one day will turn into another and you'll realize, you're not going anywhere for a long while! big hugs LIttleFlower
